body: closing due to no response
closing due to no response. Feel free to reopen if there is a reproducer available and it still is reproducible on a current version of NB.
going to close this since the issue was filed against NB 13 and we are at 19 now. This is likely already fixed as mentioned above.
closing due to no activity, link above describes how to configure java modules.

Just for completeness, running with nb-javac uninstalled is meant to be used when the JDK and nb-javac version are "close enough", which typically mean they are from the same JDK release version. I would suggest to try a build from NetBeans master for now if JDK 21 support is desired.

I can start a PR though, if anyone would show up doing the real CSS work, I can make sure that those styles are applied in the "Viewer"
No further impl or investigation after 2 weeks of the last comment?

I use this plugin https://github.com/Chris2011/ShowIgnoredFiles (it has some bugs but it is better then nothing) and I think a similar thing should be a part of the Projects view out of the box. There are many files which are connected to a project and I have to switch to Files. For example Spotbugs, PMD, `.gitignore`, `README.md`, pipeline configurations (`.gitlab-ci.yaml`), Kubernetes/helm configurations. 
It would be really nice to have an option to include all these files and folders to the Project Files or create a new node Other Files.

![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/614424/5fbe34cb-0a77-4b05-9ad3-2a609267f12d)
I can do the css :)
In version 18, on ubuntu 22 that uses snap, the problem persists. In addition, the problem is appeared in some classes.
duplicate of #3962
@thanasis-oob this change is in NetBeans 19, see milestone.

I strongly vote against a merge of project and files view. However, some improvements could be made:

* make additional files visible in project view (e.g. Jenkinsfile, ...) , there was a plugin doing that, but I don't find it anymore
* allow to filter projects view (e.g. hide dependency / test-dependency folder)
* somehow improve navigating project view with many open folder nodes (dependency, src), one is permanently scrolling
* add an actual project view: show only project for active file, or something like a subgroup for the actual project group, since project group switching is kind of slow
* dockable version of open documents dialog

Java 
* add more information into class icons of project view (visibility, final, module information)

Those are java maven project remarks. Maybe for gradle or ant build projects there are other improvement ideas.
Moving this over to discussions.  There isn't anything specifically actionable here at the moment.  Various things discussed could be separate issues or PRs.
This is hopefully resolved in NetBeans 19.  Please comment here if you see the problem again.

I cannot reproduce. 
The download page https://www.apache.org/dyn/closer.cgi/netbeans/netbeans/18/netbeans-18-bin.zip leads to valid zip for me.

Using windows default unzip.

The installer works fine with (most) non-Oracle JDKs as long as they're registered in the system during installation.  Making sure `JAVA_HOME` is set might be enough.

You could also use the community installer with a localized JDK runtime (which is actually Azul JDK 20).
Make sure to verify against the hash after downloading (as well as using trying the default unzip as mentioned).

Nope. JAVA_HOME is set to a valid Azul ZULU Java 17 JDK installation path. All other tools that depend on the JAVA_HOME variable are working fine. Still can't install NetBeans 18 IDE cause of Missing-JDK-Error.

Possibly some extant remains on the path or in the registry?!  You can also try running the installer from the CLI passing in `--javahome <JDK_PATH>`.

The JDK search is not "unnecessary harassment".  The ASF installer is written in Java - it needs to find Java for it to work!

As I said, your hassle free option is to try the community installer, which is built with NBPackage and bundles the runtime.

Thx for your review @matthiasblaesing. Yes I already encountered the missing xml part but this was done by a merge because I already had it. I didn't have a merge conflict but it was removed accidentally. And indeed this is why we need tests for this. So I changed this now back to draft, because I already created the first test but it is still red due to not triggering the warning/suggestion handled as a error. After this I will change this back to normal.

Also I will have a look into the part that you wrote with the visit method change and the new added empty space. Thx.

The NetBeans18 installation program worked fine for me on Windows 10 with Zulu JDK.
I've been testing NetBeans19 so I've been installing and un-installing NetBeans on Windows anyway, so I tested the NetBeans18's  "exe" installation program on Windows 10 just for giggles.
I have Zulu 8, 11, and 17 installed in my "C:\Program Files\Java\" directory. I have Zulu 17 as the default so it's set up in my PATH and JAVA_HOME environmental variables on boot up.
The installation program found Zulu 17 just fine and also found the Zulu 8 and 11 installations   The installation JDK text box drop-down showed all of the JDKs installed in the "C:\Program Files\Java\".  
I uninstalled NetBeans18 and then installed the test build of NetBeans19 with the same result.

@bradvido Thank you for this excellent test code and video! In my case, on Windows 11, the bug does _not_ seem to reproduce after 25 iterations:

![nobug](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/886243/76daae48-8fd6-42e4-a730-72435eb3a9ca)

However, I do observe the bug in the wild every now and then on the same setup. I will try CopyPasteTest again the next time I observe the bug in the wild, to see if there's something that changed in my environment.

(My environment:)
A custom build of NetBeans 18.0.
Java: 17.0.5; OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM 17.0.5+8-LTS
Runtime: OpenJDK Runtime Environment 17.0.5+8-LTS
System: Windows 11 version 10.0 running on amd64; Cp1252; en_US (nb)
@troizet Please attach screenshots with a dark theme. Thanks!
Merging.

Thanks for putting the issue in the tracker.  Sorry to hear of the issues.  It looks like this is a Gradle web application utilizing Jakarta EE 10 which is encountering the issues.  Have you tried to see if you have the same issues when creating a Maven web project using Jakarta EE 10?  If you see the same issues with a Maven web project, then please make sure you try to use a new userdir to see if that helps.

@DevCharly It should be disabled on Linux by default. Visual Studio Code disable it too: microsoft/vscode#65608. How can I change this?

I set the "do not merge" flag, as the author information is invalid for this: `jkost <jkost@users.noreply.github.com>`. This looks like the crap github produces when using its utilities. Please check either your local history with a good git tool (git log) or check this:

https://patch-diff.githubusercontent.com/raw/apache/netbeans/pull/6384.patch

You can see, that the author information neither holds your real name, nor a valid e-mail address. At the chance, that I sound like a broken record: I strongly advise not to use the github to do anything, that is more complex, than a simple merge. If you need to rebase or squash, do that locally, I have yet to see a sane  commit from githubs systems.

this is duplicate of #3962,

I tried Netbeans 19 the work around has no effect now and this PR is more urgent than ever. Not a particular fan of the new pkg installer, it's only meant for distributing libraries and it prevents the work around I mentioned above.
so what is the solution I just reported a bug, but it was closed by duplication.
@sysmat, no solution yet, just investigation but no formal solution yet
Please feel free to get in touch if you need any help with this!

This bug is alive so long. This eventually will appear in all new windows users, anyone will face it sooner or later, I suggest an immediate introduction of the FINEST log flag to the default installation. I propose to introduce the FINEST flag in the next release as a temporary workaround until a final fix. Otherwise new windows users will freak out.

great! @demitriusbelai can you squash everything and force push into the PR branch? The resulting commit will be merged as-is.

Since PRs are linked from the release notes, I think it would be nice here to describe in the PR text where to find the option (tools->options->appearance->flatlaf->window decorations).

First rule of debugging: reducing the frequency of a bug will decrease the likelihood of it ever getting fixed. There is nothing worse than nasty bug that occurs infrequently enough to never get fixed.

I, for one, hope that someone finds a way to make this bug occur *more* often. The more windows users freak out, the more eyeballs this issue will receive.

The bug is open for 1 and 1/2 years. At the end you will loose all windows users trying to debug it. And probably will not get anything new except frustration. And there are cases (rare?) that "FINEST" will offer ... nothing.

> Not a particular fan of the new pkg installer, it's only meant for distributing libraries and it prevents the work around I mentioned above.

I'm not sure what you mean by the "only meant for distributing libraries" comment?  Using `pkg`?  The old installer was the same, just broken in multiple other ways.

We might look at shipping the app bundle directly in a dmg or zip (easier and preferred in my opinion).  I doubt this will make a difference for you - everything is now signed with the hardened runtime and the launcher is universal architecture when no JDK is specified.  So, altering files in the bundle is not possible, and the fact that the launcher architecture might have fooled macOS in some circumstances was a happy accident.

You could use nbpackage to build from the zip yourself, forcing the launcher to x86_64 rather than universal, or just look at one of various macOS options to force use of Rosetta for the launcher?  That might still work.

Simply put, we need to fix this properly by finding a way to work with the correct architecture, ideally by NB20.
So I think not triggering Rosetta is governed by how app is installed. DMG method before and I think it should be brought back, helps installing side by side.
I think I'll stick to Netbeans 18, I really have no clue why this issue has been open for three years.

Partly agree with @cowwoc although it's not about eyes, but having a contributor (or someone willing to contribute) who can reproduce the problem, and then narrow down an actual fix.  We do not even know whether the ultimate cause of the issue is in NetBeans itself, or JDK / OS interaction with particular Swing APIs - IntelliJ has a similar and about as active bug report right now.

There is no way we're adding finest logging to the default installation, and causing unnecessary spamming of the logs on Linux, macOS, and unaffected Windows systems.  That won't make this issue any easier to fix, but might make tracking other issues more "fun"!

One thing an affected user could do is make sure they can replicate the issue in a self-built IDE.  Then try a build commenting out the actual finest level logging code in NbClipboard, in particular in https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/platform/o.n.bootstrap/src/org/netbeans/NbClipboard.java#L288  But keep the code that builds the string that is logged.  It would be good to see whether it is the eager extraction of the clipboard contents or the logging process itself that is mitigating this issue.

The previous installer was still a `pkg`, just inside a `dmg`!  It has nothing to do with the change in the triggering of Rosetta.  That is because the Swift launcher in NB18 was built with `x86_64` and the one in NB19 is built with universal architecture.
I didn't see that that would explain it.

I think then windows users should be informed / warned for this as a potential bug in one of the main web pages, describe it maybe in the download page, do not let users wondering what it is going on.  A warning note will not harm. What do I think?
Also an unnecessary change, and it stopped the terminal from working.

Yes, a PR for the known issues section on https://github.com/apache/netbeans-website/blob/master/netbeans.apache.org/src/content/download/nb19/index.adoc including link to this issue and possible ways to mitigate the problem would be welcomed!

> Also an unnecessary change, and it stopped the terminal from working.

The changes were a necessary part of fixing #6052 and other related issues.  The changes were also tested and discussed at https://lists.apache.org/thread/gvp7s1l1s0lkltmm5q7q2q1gxc38wnll

NetBeans does not yet fully support running on macOS Arm unfortunately.  You can run on an `x86_64` JDK and use `arm64` JDKs for projects.

Personally, I'd prefer we stopped shipping a macOS installer without bundled JDK runtime anyway - using the zip in those circumstances is preferable IMO for a multitude of reasons.  Either directly, or by running NBPackage on the zip with a JDK of your choice.

@ebarboni regenerated and fixed against current master.  Just waiting for tests.

In future we might want to consider doing this via delivery, with a second merge commit?  The commit is not an accurate snapshot of APIs, as it includes changes to sigfiles from master since branch.
LGTM by the way. Any workflow that ease is welcome

BTW. This seems to be some kind of synchronization issue. What about to try a workaround using the old ways, just sleep the thread here and there (probably where we do the logging) for a few ms, then see if that's improve the situation or not.

I'm thinking something like: https://github.com/lkishalmi/netbeans/commit/434a990831b43e5cf92163a7dee14594776beddd

Well, again I'm in the fortunate situation, having no Windows around...
@lkishalmi feel free to open a draft PR and label it with https://github.com/apache/netbeans/labels/ci%3Adev-build so that those who are affected by this can test it.
replaced by #6415

> @lkishalmi feel free to open a draft PR and label it with [ ci:dev-build](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/labels/ci%3Adev-build) [ci] produce a dev-build zip artifact (7 days expiration, see link on workflow summary page) so that those who are affected by this can test it.

Here you are: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/6418

I agree, we need better support for macOS Arm.

Each release I manually copy the binaries I built on my M1 mac to the new Netbeans folder to get the terminal to work.

I run straight ARM jdk using SDKMAN and things work fine.

If it would help I can make a GitHub repo with my folder that I built for the ARM support to get the terminal working.

It's not perfect, but it will get your terminal working again.

@DevCharly the other thing to check with @rkeen-siemens is that the quick patch (#6294) I had to make to his dialog fix hasn't caused the original issue to reappear.

See also the original issue report at #5987 to see why it might be of concern here.

> Some comments below. It's not clear to me how the binary is downloaded. We may want to upload it to the OSWUL server. Let me know if you need help on this.

This is not necessary and run contrary to the intention of the extension. The "external" file is used at installation time (aka runtime)  to fetch the referenced binary. If I remember correctly, this mechanism was introduced to make it possible to create NBMs bundling libraries, not compatbile with GPLv2/CDDL and distribute these with the IDE/derived products. That also answers the question about the external file. This file has (a) not enough to content to be copyrightable by itself (IANAL!) and (b) I assume @jkost created the file, so he is author and in this case I don't see why it should not be ALv2. It _references_ non-ASF material, but that is also true for the OpenJFX integration.
I don't mind this patch, but I wonder if there would be opportunity to solve this in the infrastructure, e.g. by synthesizing some ClasspathInfo when none is provided for this task?

> > Some comments below. It's not clear to me how the binary is downloaded. We may want to upload it to the OSWUL server. Let me know if you need help on this.
> 
> This is not necessary and run contrary to the intention of the extension. The "external" file is used at installation time (aka runtime) to fetch the referenced binary. If I remember correctly, this mechanism was introduced to make it possible to create NBMs bundling libraries, not compatbile with GPLv2/CDDL and distribute these with the IDE/derived products. That also answers the question about the external file. This file has (a) not enough to content to be copyrightable by itself (IANAL!) and (b) I assume @jkost created the file, so he is author and in this case I don't see why it should not be ALv2. It _references_ non-ASF material, but that is also true for the OpenJFX integration.

Ah, pretty cool then. We're good!

Support for @supports was added about four years ago. There are explicit tests for @supports in the project:

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/1e494096b524d4c302eb34cca60977ba3955f6df/ide/css.lib/test/unit/src/org/netbeans/modules/css/lib/Css3ParserTest.java#L734-L909

So please add concrete cases, that fail for you.
+1 To adding `After Use Trait`

> I don't mind this patch, but I wonder if there would be opportunity to solve this in the infrastructure, e.g. by synthesizing some ClasspathInfo when none is provided for this task?

It is hard to create any ClasspathInfo without a FileObject (before any project or file gets opened)
this might help with #4853 and #4852
@mbien any news on the Graal? Moss is growing fat on this PR.

> I set the "do not merge" flag, as the author information is invalid for this: ...

The other invalid author information is that, while @jkost is on the PMC, the GitHub account is not linked to the ASF membership.  Which also links it to validation of identity, ICLA, etc.  Please fix this before the PR is merged.

> We may want to upload it to the OSWUL server. Let me know if you need help on this.

I realise this is not relevant to this PR.  But as a general comment, my understanding was that OSUOSL was a legacy, transitional mechanism.  Ideally we'd be, and have been, moving things away from it, not adding more to it.

Thanks @ebarboni Tests look good so merging.

> Any workflow that ease is welcome

It won't make it any easier!  It will just ensure that there is a commit somewhere that actually contains an accurate snapshot.

Actually, this looks fine, merging - I already changed L67 in #6240

I guess there is an argument that NB19 is a previous version if you're using a daily build though?! :shrug:
